title: HK pledges support for WHO hand-washing campaign (with photo)
content_text:
p>The Secretary for Health, Welfare and Food, Dr York Chow, pledged Hong Kong's 
support for a World Health Organisation's (WHO) campaign in promoting hand 
hygiene as an effective means to counter the spread of infectious disease. The pledge was delivered via video conferencing during the launch ceremony of 
the WHO's campaign, "Global Patient Safety Challenge: Clean Care is Safer Care", 
in Geneva, Switzerland today (October 13).  While delivering the pledge, Dr Chow said Hong Kong supported the WHO's event 
and was committed to promoting good hand hygiene to control the spread of

and was committed to promoting good hand hygiene to control the spread of 
infectious diseases in both healthcare settings and in the community.  Representatives from local medical and healthcare professions, including the 
Director of Health, Dr PY Lam, and the Controller of the Department of Health's 
Centre for Health Protection, Dr PY Leung, were present to witness the delivery 
and signing of the pledge and show their unanimous support for the WHO's 
initiative. To further heighten public awareness on good hand hygiene, the Department of 
Health will step up promotional efforts by launching a territory-wide campaign,

Health will step up promotional efforts by launching a territory-wide campaign, 
"Wash Hands for Better Health" early next year. The campaign aims to remind the 
public that good hand hygiene is the first line of defence against infectious 
diseases, and it is hoped that the campaign will help create a social 
environment conducive to good hand hygiene.  Special emphasis will be placed on community settings like schools, shopping 
malls and food premises. A host of health promotion materials, including a new 
pamphlet, posters and eye-catching stickers, will be produced to drive home the

pamphlet, posters and eye-catching stickers, will be produced to drive home the 
message. Multi-media channels including websites and 24-hour health education 
hotline will be used.
